## Steps to reproduce

```powershell
[System.Text.Encoding]::Default

```

## Expected behavior

```none
BodyName          : gb2312
EncodingName      : Chinese Simplified (GB2312)
HeaderName        : gb2312
WebName           : gb2312
WindowsCodePage   : 936
IsBrowserDisplay  : True
IsBrowserSave     : True
IsMailNewsDisplay : True
IsMailNewsSave    : True
IsSingleByte      : False
EncoderFallback   : System.Text.InternalEncoderBestFitFallback
DecoderFallback   : System.Text.InternalDecoderBestFitFallback
IsReadOnly        : True
CodePage          : 936

```

## Actual behavior

```none
Preamble          :
BodyName          : utf-8
EncodingName      : Unicode (UTF-8)
HeaderName        : utf-8
WebName           : utf-8
WindowsCodePage   : 1200
IsBrowserDisplay  : True
IsBrowserSave     : True
IsMailNewsDisplay : True
IsMailNewsSave    : True
IsSingleByte      : False
EncoderFallback   : System.Text.EncoderReplacementFallback
DecoderFallback   : System.Text.DecoderReplacementFallback
IsReadOnly        : True
CodePage          : 65001
```

comments.author: jborean93
comments.body:
On .NET Core this is expected https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.text.encoding.default?view=net-5.0 > On .NET Core, the Default property always returns the UTF8Encoding. UTF-8 is supported on all the operating systems (Windows, Linux, and macOS) on which .NET Core applications run. It will no longer use the active codepage like Windows PowerShell (.NET Framework) did. If you want to get the console codepage then `[Console]::OutputEncoding` and `[Console]::InputEncoding` is more relevant.
Encoding.Default Property (System.Text)
Gets the default encoding for this .NET implementation.

comments.author: jborean93
comments.body:
If you wish to get the same value as `[Text.Encoding]::Default` did in Windows PowerShell then you can use the following:

```powershell
Add-Type -Namespace Kernel32 -Name NativeMethods -MemberDefinition @'
[DllImport("Kernel32.dll")]
public static extern int GetACP();
'@

[Text.Encoding]::GetEncoding([Kernel32.NativeMethods]::GetACP())
```

What you use really depends on what you are using this encoding value for.

comments.author: jborean93
comments.body:
As far as I know "ANSI" in notepad refers to the system codepage which as you said `[Text.Encoding]::Default` used to refer to. It's a bit of a loaded term unfortunately but that ship sailed years ago.

See my other comment https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/15230#issuecomment-819202122 on how to get that value in a way that would work with both Windows PowerShell and PowerShell.

Ultimately if you are saving files it is recommended to use UTF-8, potentially UTF-8 with BOM if you need compatibility with some older hosts. UTF-8 is more universal and well known on modern systems so it's really the way forward. It's also the same on any host, i.e. utf-8 on 1 host is the same on the other, compared to ANSI where it can refer to different encoding schemes.

comments.body: Yea it’s not recommended because a lot of tools on Linux don’t support the BOM for UTF-8. It’s really a mixed bag and you can probably safely use just utf-8 without a BOM but it’s highly dependent on your environment and what is consuming the files.
